prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Defences to Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: When restrictive clauses are vague or are not reasonably limited in time[1] or geographic area,[2] they will be declared void. In Quantum Management Services Ltd. v. Hann,[3] a restrictive covenant was declared void because it prevented the defendants from providing any support to any competitor of the plaintiff, whereas the court held that only protection with respect to clients developed and recruited by the defendants was required.
Maguire v. Northland Drug Co., [1935) 3 D.L.R. 521 at pp. 524 5, [1935] S.C.R. 412.
Drake International Inc. v. Tennenbaum (1986), 10 C.P.R. (3d) 119 (Ont. H.C.J.), at p. 122.
Quantum Management Services Ltd. v. Hann (1989), 69 O.R. (2d) 26, 43 B.L.R. 93 (H.C.J.), affd 11 O.R. (3d) 639, 45 C.P.R. (3d) 498 (C.A.).
